They’d say, *"Hey, you look nice."* But then the smile would falter, just a little, just enough for me to notice, and their eyes would flick away, and I’d know. I’d *know*. *"You look nice,"* they’d say, but what they’d mean is, *"I don’t know how to tell you this, but I’ve been thinking about how much I don’t actually like you."* I press my palms into my eyes. *Stop. Stop. They’re not like that. They’ve never been like that.* But the voice in my head is louder, sharper, a knife twisting— *"You’re too much. You’re always too much. The way you text, the way you laugh, the way you look at me like I’m the only person in the room—it’s suffocating. No one wants to be worshipped like that."* I swallow. My throat is dry. I should’ve brought water. I should’ve brought *something*. A gift, maybe. A peace offering. But what if it’s the wrong thing? What if they take it and smile and say, *"Oh, thanks,"* but what they really mean is, *"This is weird. Why are you giving me things? Are you trying to buy my affection?"* *God, I’m so tired.* I sit on the edge of the bed, then stand up again. I can’t sit still. If I sit still, I’ll start spiraling. I’ll start imagining the worst-case scenario, the one where they don’t show up at all. The one where I text them—*"Hey, everything okay?"*—and they don’t reply for hours, and then when they do, it’s just—*"Sorry, got caught up. Rain check?"* And I’ll say, *"Sure, no problem,"* but what I’ll mean is, *"You’re lying. You don’t want to see me. You never wanted to see me."* And then I’ll hate myself for saying *"no problem"* when it’s *such a problem*, when it’s *the* problem, when every cell in my body is screaming that this is it, this is the moment, this is when they finally realize I’m not worth the effort. *Stop. Just stop. They’re coming. They’re probably just stuck in traffic. Or their phone died. Or they’re running late because they had to finish something at work. It doesn’t mean anything.* But what if it *does*? What if they’ve been distant because they’re trying to figure out how to tell me they don’t feel the same way? What if they’ve been rehearsing it in their head, the same way I’m rehearsing my responses now? *"I think we should just be friends."* *"I need space."* *"I’m not ready for this."* I can see it so clearly—the way their face would fall, the way they’d look at me with pity, the way they’d reach out like they’re trying to soften the blow, and I’d flinch away because I can’t stand the thought of them touching me when they don’t *want* to. *No. No, they wouldn’t do that. They’re not like that. They’ve been nothing but kind. They’ve been patient. They’ve been—* *"Patient."* The word tastes bitter. *Patient* means they’re tolerating me. *Patient* means they’re counting down the days until they can politely extricate themselves from this mess. I check my phone again. 7:18. Still no text. Still no call. My battery is at 2% now. *Fuck.* What if they’re already here and I missed them? What if they came early and saw me pacing like a lunatic and left? What if they’re sitting in the café right now, watching me through the window, thinking, *"Jesus, she’s unhinged,"* and then they’ll ghost me, and I’ll never know why, and I’ll spend the next six months dissecting every interaction, every word, every look, trying to figure out where I went wrong. *You’re being ridiculous. They’re not like that. They’re not going to ghost you. They’re not going to—* But what if they are? What if this is the night? What if this is the night they finally see me for what I am—a needy, clingy, emotionally volatile disaster who latches onto people like a barnacle, who can’t handle the slightest shift in tone without spiraling, who turns every conversation into a referendum on whether or not they still love me? *You’re not that bad.* *Yes, I am.* *No, you’re not. You’re just—* *Just what? Sensitive? Dramatic? A burden?* I exhale sharply. My hands are shaking. I should’ve taken my meds earlier. I should’ve eaten something. I should’ve— The knock at the door makes me jump. For a second, I just stare at it. My heart is in my throat. *They’re early. They’re early and I’m not ready. I’m never ready.* Another knock. Softer this time. *"Hey. You in there?"* Their voice. Their *actual* voice. Not the one in my head, not the one that’s been whispering poison all evening. The real one. Warm. Familiar. I don’t move. Because what if I open the door and they’re not alone? What if they’ve brought someone else, some friend, some *ex*, and they’re all laughing and I’m just the weird girl who thought this was a date when it was never a date at all? *"You okay?"* I swallow. *"Yeah. Yeah, just—one sec."* I take a breath. Then another. My hands are still shaking. I wipe them on my jeans. *Okay. Okay. You can do this. It’s just them. It’s just—* I open the door. And there they are. Smiling. *"Hey,"* they say. *"You look nice."* And just like that, the fist around my ribs loosens. Just a little. But then— Then I see the way their eyes flick to my phone, still clutched in my hand, the screen dark. The way they hesitate, just for a second, before stepping inside. And the voice is back. *"Oh, you’re still holding your phone. Were you waiting for someone else to text you? Or were you just too nervous to put it down?"* No. No, that’s not— *"You’re overthinking,"* they say, and they reach out, tuck a strand of hair behind my ear. *"I’m sorry I’m late. Traffic was a nightmare."* Their fingers brush my cheek. Warm. Real. And I want to believe them. I *want* to. But then— Then they pull away, and their smile falters, just a little, just enough for me to notice, and I *know*. I *know* they’re lying. *"It’s fine,"* I say, and my voice is too bright, too forced. *"I wasn’t waiting for anything."* They frown. *"You sure? You seem—"* *"I’m fine,"* I snap, and then immediately hate myself. *"Sorry. I’m just—"* *"Tired?"* they offer. *"Yeah. Tired."* They nod, but their eyes are searching mine, like they’re trying to find the right thing to say, the thing that will make this better, the thing that will make me *stop*. And that’s when I know for sure. They’re done. They’re *done*. *"You know what?"* I say, before I can stop myself. *"Maybe we should just—"* *"Hey."* They step closer, their hands on my shoulders. *"What’s going on in that head of yours?"* *"Nothing."* *"Liar."* I flinch. Because they’re right. I *am* a liar. I’m always lying. I’m lying when I say I’m fine. I’m lying when I say I don’t care. I’m lying when I pretend I don’t need them to prove, over and over, that they’re not going to leave. *"You’ve been distant,"* I say, and my voice cracks. *"And I get it, I do, but—"* *"Distant?"* They look genuinely confused. *"Babe, I’ve been swamped at work. You know that."* *"But you haven’t texted as much."* *"Because I’ve been in meetings all day. You know how it is."* *"But what if it’s not that?"* The words spill out before I can stop them. *"What if it’s because you don’t—"* *"Don’t what?"* Their voice is gentle, but there’s an edge to it now. *"Don’t love you? Is that what you’re about to say?"* I don’t answer. I can’t. Because the truth is, I *do* think that. I think it every day. I think it every time they don’t text back fast enough, every time they cancel plans, every time they look at me with that *look*—the one that says they’re tired of this, tired of *me*. *"I’m sorry,"* I whisper. *"I just—"* *"You just what?"* They sigh, and for a second, I’m sure they’re going to walk out. I’m sure this is it. *"You just assume the worst. Every time. No matter what I do, no matter what I say, you always think I’m about to leave."* *"Because you will,"* I say, and the words are out before I can stop them. *"Everyone does."* They go still. And for a second, I think I’ve ruined it. I think I’ve pushed too far. But then— Then they pull me into their arms. *"I’m not going anywhere,"* they murmur into my hair. *"I’m right here. I’m *here*."* And for a second, just a second, I let myself believe them. But then my phone buzzes in my pocket. 1%. One percent. And I know— I know it’s only a matter of time.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of borderline personality disorder and the internal experience of anticipatory rejection. The author successfully creates an immersive first-person narrative that captures the exhausting cycle of catastrophic thinking, emotional dysregulation, and the desperate need for validation coupled with immediate suspicion of it. The structure effectively alternates between the protagonist's spiraling internal monologue and the actual interaction, showing the stark contrast between imagined scenarios and reality. The writing captures the cognitive dissonance beautifully - how the character simultaneously craves and fears connection, how they construct elaborate defensive narratives while recognizing (but being unable to stop) the pattern. The prose style effectively mirrors the character's mental state through fragmented thoughts, repetitive patterns, and escalating anxiety. The use of italics to distinguish between different levels of internal dialogue works well, creating layers of self-awareness and self-criticism. The phone battery serving as a countdown device adds tangible urgency to the abstract emotional crisis. However, the piece suffers from some repetitiveness that, while psychologically accurate, becomes somewhat tedious for the reader. The internal monologue, though authentic, occasionally feels overwrought and could benefit from more varied pacing. Some moments feel slightly performative in their psychological accuracy rather than naturally emerging from character. The ending effectively maintains the cycle without false resolution, showing how even genuine reassurance gets filtered through the character's distorted lens. The final image of the dying phone battery suggests the ongoing nature of this struggle. The dialogue, when it appears, feels natural and serves the story well. The character's responses feel believable and consistent with someone experiencing this level of emotional dysregulation. The piece successfully avoids both romanticizing and demonizing mental illness, presenting it as a complex, exhausting reality. + Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 66.3
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Blood Debt** The torch guttered in the damp air, its flickering light carving jagged shadows across the crumbling stone of the abandoned temple. The roof had long since collapsed in places, leaving gaps where the moon bled pale silver onto the cracked flagstones. Around the makeshift arena, the crowd pressed close—Jigen-ryū disciples in their stiff, formal *hakama*, their faces sharp with disdain, and the rougher, leather-clad followers of Piguaquan, their eyes bright with the thrill of forbidden combat. At the center of it all stood **Kenshiro of Jigen-ryū**, his posture rigid as a drawn blade. His *haori* was discarded, revealing the corded muscle of his arms, the sleeves of his *gi* rolled to the elbows. His fingers twitched at his sides, as if already gripping the hilt of an invisible sword. Across from him, **Li Wei of Piguaquan** moved with the restless energy of a caged tiger, his bare feet whispering over the stone. His loose, sleeveless tunic fluttered with each shift of his weight, the fabric clinging to the sweat already beading on his skin. No words were exchanged. There was no need. Kenshiro struck first. His body coiled like a spring, then *unleashed*—a lunging step, his lead hand snapping forward in a *tsuki* that would have shattered a man’s sternum. But Li Wei was already gone, his torso twisting sideways in a whipping motion, his own counter lashing out like a bullwhip. His palm cracked against Kenshiro’s ribs, not with the force to break bone, but enough to stagger him. The Jigen-ryū fighter recovered instantly, pivoting on his back foot, his other hand flashing upward in a rising elbow. Li Wei ducked beneath it, his shoulder slamming into Kenshiro’s midsection. The impact sent them both crashing into the crowd, bodies tumbling over each other before they rolled apart, springing to their feet in the same instant. The crowd roared. Kenshiro’s breath came in sharp, controlled bursts. He circled left, forcing Li Wei toward the edge of the torchlight, where the shadows pooled thickest. The Piguaquan fighter grinned, his teeth glinting in the firelight. He *wanted* to be there. Then he *moved*. Not forward—*around*. His footwork was a blur of shuffling steps, his body swaying like a reed in the wind. Kenshiro lunged again, a straight punch aimed at his throat, but Li Wei’s arm deflected it with a circular parry, his other hand slashing diagonally at Kenshiro’s temple. The Jigen-ryū fighter barely managed to jerk his head back, feeling the wind of the strike kiss his cheek. Too close. Kenshiro seized the opening, grabbing Li Wei’s wrist and yanking him forward. His knee came up in a brutal *hiza geri*, but Li Wei twisted at the last second, taking the blow on his thigh instead of his ribs. Pain flared, but he used it, driving his elbow down into Kenshiro’s collarbone. The Jigen-ryū fighter grunted, his grip loosening just enough for Li Wei to wrench free. They reset, breathing hard. The torchlight painted their faces in gold and black, highlighting the sweat, the clenched jaws, the murder in their eyes. Kenshiro’s next attack was a feint—a low kick, easily dodged—then a sudden upward palm strike aimed at Li Wei’s chin. The Piguaquan fighter leaned back, but Kenshiro was already spinning, his other leg whipping around in a *mawashi geri*. The kick caught Li Wei in the side, sending him skidding across the stone. He rolled, coming up in a crouch, his fingers splayed against the ground for balance. The crowd held its breath. Li Wei *laughed*. Then he *exploded*. His body uncoiled like a spring, his lead hand slashing in a horizontal arc, his back foot pivoting to generate torque. The strike was a blur, a whip-crack of motion, and Kenshiro barely got his forearm up in time. The impact shuddered through his bones, but he retaliated instantly, driving his fist into Li Wei’s floating ribs. The Piguaquan fighter gasped, but his other hand was already rising, his fingers hooked into claws, aiming for Kenshiro’s eyes. Kenshiro jerked his head back, but the strike grazed his cheek, drawing blood. He snarled, grabbing Li Wei’s wrist and *twisting*, forcing the smaller man to his knees. His other hand came down in a hammerfist, but Li Wei rolled with it, using the momentum to flip back to his feet, his own counter—a spinning backfist—catching Kenshiro square in the jaw. Teeth clacked. Blood sprayed. Kenshiro staggered, but he didn’t fall. Instead, he *charged*. His shoulder slammed into Li Wei’s gut, lifting him off his feet and slamming him into the ground. The impact knocked the wind from the Piguaquan fighter’s lungs, but he wrapped his legs around Kenshiro’s waist, locking him in place. His fists rained down—short, brutal punches to the kidneys, the ribs, the base of the spine. Kenshiro roared, driving his forehead into Li Wei’s nose. Cartilage crunched. Blood gushed. Li Wei’s grip loosened just enough for Kenshiro to break free, staggering back, his vision swimming. The torchlight flickered. For a heartbeat, neither moved. Then, like wolves circling, they closed again. This time, there were no feints. No clever footwork. Just raw, desperate violence. Kenshiro’s fist crashed into Li Wei’s temple. Li Wei’s knee drove into Kenshiro’s gut. They grappled, twisted, fell—rolling across the stone, each trying to gain the upper hand. At one point, Kenshiro had Li Wei in a chokehold, his forearm crushing the Piguaquan fighter’s throat. Li Wei’s fingers clawed at his eyes, his nails drawing blood, and Kenshiro was forced to release him. They came apart, gasping. The crowd was a living thing now, howling, stamping their feet, the sound echoing through the ruins like the roar of a distant storm. Li Wei wiped blood from his split lip. Kenshiro’s knuckles were raw, his breath ragged. They had both given everything. And yet— Neither had fallen. The torch sputtered. In the sudden dimness, Kenshiro’s voice cut through the noise, low and fierce. *"Enough."* Li Wei grinned, blood staining his teeth. *"Coward."* Kenshiro’s answer was a single, decisive step forward. And then they were moving again.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution in several key areas while falling short in others. The author successfully maintains the requested physical coherence throughout the fight sequence, clearly tracking both fighters' positions and movements in space. The choreography is well-conceived, with strikes, counters, and spatial dynamics that allow readers to visualize the action effectively. The setting of the crumbling temple is vividly established and consistently maintained. The writing captures the brutal intensity of underground combat effectively, with visceral descriptions of impacts and injuries that feel authentic. The author demonstrates good understanding of both martial arts styles, incorporating appropriate techniques and philosophies. The pacing builds tension well, escalating from initial strikes to desperate grappling. However, the piece suffers from significant characterization weaknesses. Beyond their fighting styles and basic social backgrounds, Kenshiro and Li Wei remain essentially interchangeable. Their motivations are generic, and neither displays meaningful personality traits or internal conflict beyond surface-level pride. The "generations-old rivalry" feels like window dressing rather than genuine emotional fuel. The dialogue is minimal and functional but lacks distinctiveness - both characters could have spoken each other's lines without any tonal shift. The ending, while dramatically appropriate, doesn't provide meaningful resolution or insight into either character. The prose occasionally veers toward overwrought territory with phrases like "murder in their eyes" and repetitive structural patterns, though it generally maintains readability. Some descriptions feel slightly purple, particularly in the atmospheric passages. The piece succeeds as an action sequence but fails to achieve deeper emotional resonance or character development that would elevate it beyond competent genre writing. + Physical-spatial: Breaking Formation — Score: 75.5
Prompt:
**"Breaking Formation"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood who's won a scholarship to an elite K-pop training academy in Seoul. Desperately out of place culturally and technically, they struggle with a militaristically precise choreography that contradicts everything about their improvisational background. The punishing rehearsal takes place under a famous instructor known for breaking students to remake them, who sees potential in the narrator's raw talent but not their attitude. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—each dance move, position shift, and spatial relationship must be tracked with precision throughout the studio. Paint an exceptionally vivid kinetic picture through descriptions that capture not just movement but the contrast between the narrator's fluid, expressive style and the mechanical precision demanded. Their internal monologue should reveal culture shock, class anxiety, and the threatening realization that success here might mean losing their authentic movement voice. Include technical terminology that highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, moments when muscle memory betrays them, and a crucial decision point about whether to conform or rebel. Physical clarity is essential—readers must be able to visualize exactly how bodies move through space, how rhythms align or clash, and how the protagonist's body struggles against unfamiliar discipline. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**"Breaking Formation"** The studio is a glass cage. Floor-to-ceiling mirrors reflect the same brutal geometry from every angle—my body, twisted wrong, my limbs refusing to snap into the right angles. The digital clock on the wall ticks down: *01:47:23*. One hour, forty-seven minutes, twenty-three seconds until the showcase. Until I prove I belong here. Until I don’t. I’m used to dancing in alleys where the pavement cracks under my sneakers, where the beat drops like a punch and the crowd’s energy bends the rhythm. Here, the floor is sprung wood, silent and unforgiving. The music is a metronome’s wet dream—*120 BPM, 4/4 time, no swing, no soul*—just a grid of sound where every eighth note is a prison bar. And then there’s *him*. Master Seo stands at the front of the room, arms crossed, his reflection looming in the mirror like a judge. His eyes are sharp enough to flay skin. He’s the kind of instructor who doesn’t just teach choreography—he *dismantles* you. I’ve heard the stories. The girl who cried for a week after he made her relearn a single hip roll for eight hours. The boy who got sent home for “lacking hunger” when his turnout wasn’t clean enough. I have hunger. I have *rage*. But hunger doesn’t mean shit when your body won’t obey. The music starts again. The same eight-count phrase, looped like a noose. *Step, step, body roll, pivot turn, sharp arm, freeze.* My muscles remember the streets—*the way my spine undulates like a wave, the way my knees bend just a little deeper when the bass hits, the way my arms slice the air like I’m cutting through smoke.* But here? Here, my body is a traitor. I hit the first step—*too heavy*. My weight shifts forward when it should stay centered. The second step is *late*, my timing off by a fraction of a second, but in this room, a fraction is a chasm. The body roll is the worst. On the streets, it’s fluid, a ripple from my ribs to my hips, a conversation with the music. Here, it’s a *mechanical wave*, a controlled undulation that starts at the sternum and ends at the pelvis with a *click*, like a robot powering down. My spine doesn’t *click*. It *sings*. I try again. *Step, step—* my foot lands wrong, my ankle rolling just enough to throw off the pivot turn. My arms fly up for the sharp hit, but my elbow is *soft*, my wrist *limp*. Master Seo’s reflection doesn’t move. He doesn’t even blink. “Again.” The music resets. My breath comes in short, sharp bursts. My thighs burn. The clock ticks: *01:42:10*. --- I wasn’t built for this. Back home, dancing was survival. It was the way I talked when my voice wasn’t enough. It was the way I claimed space in a world that wanted to shrink me. In the cipher, I could *feel* the circle’s energy, could let it pull me deeper into the pocket, could ride the music like a current. Here, the music doesn’t *move* me. It *directs* me. Like a puppet on strings. And I *hate* it. But I need it. The scholarship is my ticket out. Out of the projects. Out of the cycle. Out of the life where my little brother’s biggest dream is to not get jumped on the way home from school. So I swallow the bile in my throat, and I try again. *Step. Step. Body roll.* This time, I force my spine straight. I *lock* my ribs. I make my hips move in a *box*, not a circle. The roll is *stiff*, but it’s *clean*. My pivot turn is *sharp*. My arms *snap* into place. Master Seo’s eyebrow twitches. “Better.” One word. It should feel like a victory. But my stomach twists. --- The next section is a series of *isolations*—chest pops, shoulder rolls, head snaps. On the streets, isolations are *play*. You hit one, then let it bleed into the next, let your body *breathe* between movements. Here, they’re *staccato*. *Precise*. Each one is a *bullet*, fired in perfect time. I mess up the chest pop. My sternum doesn’t *pop*—it *lurches*. My shoulders follow, throwing off the next movement. My head snaps a beat late, my neck stiff from trying to keep up. Master Seo steps forward. “Your body is *lazy*.” I bristle. “I’m not lazy.” “Then why does your movement look like you’re *drowning*?” The words hit like a slap. Because he’s right. I *am* drowning. Drowning in this room, in this music, in these expectations. My body knows how to *flow*, how to *ride*, how to *bend*—but it doesn’t know how to *obey*. He moves closer. “You have *talent*. But talent is *nothing* without control.” His finger jabs at my chest. “You dance like a *storm*. But storms *destroy*. We don’t need destruction. We need *precision*.” I want to scream. I want to tell him that storms *create*, too. That without chaos, there’s no *life*. But the clock is ticking—*01:30:45*—and I don’t have time for philosophy. --- The final section is the *killer*. A series of *jump turns*, each one ending in a *freeze* so sharp it should leave a mark on the floor. On the streets, I’d *milk* the freeze, let it hang for a second too long, let the crowd *feel* it. Here, the freeze is a *period*. A *full stop*. No emotion. No flair. Just *perfection*. I take a deep breath. I *run*. My feet leave the ground—*one and a half rotations*—and I land, my body snapping into the freeze. My arms are *straight*, my back *arched*, my chin *level*. For a second, I think I’ve done it. Then I see Master Seo’s face. “Your *eyes*.” I blink. “What?” “Your eyes are *dead*.” He steps closer. “You think this is about *moving*? It’s about *selling*. You’re not a robot. You’re a *performer*.” I want to laugh. *Selling*? That’s all I’ve ever done. I’ve sold my pain, my joy, my rage—all through movement. But here, *selling* means something different. It means *smiling* when your feet are bleeding. It means *performing* happiness when your soul is screaming. I don’t know if I can do that. --- The music stops. The clock reads *01:25:12*. Master Seo watches me, his gaze heavy. “You have two choices,” he says. “You can *break* yourself. Or you can *be broken*.” I look at my reflection in the mirror. My body is *wrong* here. My posture is too loose, my energy too wild. But it’s *mine*. And for the first time, I wonder if that’s enough. The clock ticks. *01:25:00*. I take a breath. Then I *bend*.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution in several key areas while falling short in others. The writer successfully captures the physical precision demanded by the prompt, tracking spatial relationships and movement with impressive clarity. The contrast between street dance fluidity and K-pop mechanical precision is well-established through specific technical details like "120 BPM, 4/4 time" versus the narrator's natural "undulation" and "wave-like" movements. The first-person voice remains consistent throughout, effectively conveying the protagonist's cultural displacement and internal conflict. The narrator's background comes through authentically in phrases like "dancing was survival" and references to "the projects" and protecting a younger brother. The physical descriptions are particularly strong - readers can visualize exactly how the body moves through space, from the failed pivot turns to the stiff body rolls. However, the piece suffers from some overwrought moments that border on purple prose. Phrases like "The studio is a glass cage" and "metronome's wet dream" feel forced rather than organic. The italicized emphasis becomes excessive and distracting, particularly in technical passages where it interrupts the flow rather than enhancing meaning. The emotional complexity is well-handled, showing the protagonist's genuine struggle between authenticity and conformity without easy resolution. Master Seo is effectively portrayed as intimidating yet not cartoonishly villainous. The ending avoids false positivity - the protagonist's decision to "bend" feels earned given the established stakes and internal conflict. The piece occasionally tells rather than shows, particularly in exposition about the narrator's background and the instructor's reputation. Some metaphors feel strained ("prison bar" eighth notes, "noose" of repeated music). The dialogue, while limited, serves its purpose effectively in revealing character dynamics. The writing maintains good pacing and builds tension effectively toward the crucial decision point. The physical coherence requested in the prompt is maintained throughout, with clear tracking of body positions and spatial relationships in the studio environment. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 13 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 9 Overwrought: 10 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 13.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 8.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 7.0, Purple Prose: 9.0, Overwrought: 10.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Gothic-fantasy-humour: Court of the Dreaming — Score: 83.7
Prompt:
Court of the Dreaming: Territorial Dream Dispute. Write a dark fantasy scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream where a case is being heard to determine ownership of a contested dreamscape. Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit who sits on sleepers' chests causing paralysis and terror, has recently invaded and subverted a carefully crafted recurring dream of a schoolboy, Max. The dream originally featured the boy lying in a field of wildflowers with his crush, always culminating in a muddled almost-kiss and a pleasant confusion of emotions. This dream was the meticulous work of "First Love" (a rosy-cheeked, slightly bashful entity who crafts formative romantic experiences). However, Mora has recently infiltrated the dreamscape, transforming the scene so that when the girl playfully mounts the boy, she morphs into a terrifying yet somehow still confusingly attractive vision who proceeds to sit on his chest and feed on his breath. Mora's defense largely consists of the practical argument that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" Write this scene as it unfolds in the courtroom of the Dreaming, with Dream's demeanour, typically impenetrable, betraying a sense of irritation at having to adjudicate such matters. The comedy should derive from the farcical situation, familiar elements of courtroom drama intersecting with the fantastical world of the Dreaming, and the droll portrayal of the characters and their interactions. The humor should be dark and understated throughout. Dream is tempted to some mischief in the resolution of the case. Use descriptives sparingly when setting scene. Write for readability & engagement. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**The Court of the Dreaming: *First Love v. Mora*** The Court of the Dreaming was not, strictly speaking, a *court*—not in the mortal sense. It was a vast, shifting expanse of obsidian and starlight, where the walls breathed and the floor rippled like the surface of a sleeping mind. At its center stood the Bench, a jagged slab of black marble veined with silver, upon which sat *Dream*—or, as he was currently inclined to think of himself, *Judge Dream, Presiding Over This Utter Nonsense*. He was not in a good mood. Before him stood the two disputing parties, each radiating the kind of self-righteous indignation that only immortal beings could muster over something so trivial. On the left, *First Love*—a plump, rosy-cheeked entity in a waistcoat of embroidered forget-me-nots, his fingers nervously twisting a lock of golden hair. He looked like a cherub who had been promoted too soon and was now drowning in paperwork. On the right, *Mora*—tall, gaunt, draped in tattered shadows that shifted like smoke. Her fingers ended in too-long nails, and her grin was all teeth. She emitted a faint, wet cackle that echoed uncomfortably through the vaulted ceilings, like a rat skittering behind the walls. Dream pinched the bridge of his nose. "Let me see if I understand this correctly. You," he said, gesturing to First Love, "crafted a *wholesome* recurring dream for a mortal child—a pastoral idyll of wildflowers and shy glances, culminating in the *almost*-kiss that defines the agony of adolescence." First Love nodded eagerly. "A masterpiece! A *delicate* balance of longing and innocence! The boy wakes with his heart racing, his palms sweaty—" "And *you*," Dream interrupted, turning to Mora, "decided that this was the *perfect* dreamscape to infiltrate, transforming the girl into a *nightmare* who sits on his chest, feeds on his breath, and—if I’m interpreting the boy’s frantic journal entries correctly—*also* makes him question his sexuality in the most *unsettling* way possible." Mora shrugged, her shoulders rising like a vulture’s wings. "A girl’s gotta eat, you know?" First Love gasped, clutching his chest as if mortally wounded. "She *perverted* my work! That dream was *sacred*! The boy was supposed to wake up with a smile, not *screaming into his pillow while his parents pound on the door*!" Mora rolled her eyes. "Oh, please. You act like I *ruined* it. The boy still gets his heart racing. The boy still gets his palms sweaty. The *only* difference is now he also gets a *healthy* dose of existential dread. It’s *art*." Dream exhaled through his nose, long and slow. "Mora, you are a *nightmare spirit*. Your entire *purpose* is to induce terror. You don’t get to claim *artistic integrity* when you turn a boy’s first crush into a *suffocating succubus*." Mora grinned. "I prefer *breath thief*." First Love threw his hands up. "This is *outrageous*! That dream was *mine*! I spent *centuries* perfecting the angle of the sunlight! The way the wind rustles the girl’s hair just so! The *exact* moment the almost-kiss is interrupted by a butterfly landing on his nose—" Mora snorted. "A *butterfly*? Really? That’s your big climax? No wonder the kid was *bored*. I gave him *drama*. I gave him *passion*." "*You gave him night terrors!*" Dream held up a hand. "Enough." The word carried the weight of a gavel made of lead and regret. "The question before the court is simple: Who has the greater claim to this dreamscape?" First Love puffed out his chest. "I was there *first*! I *crafted* it! It is *my* domain!" Mora tilted her head, her grin widening. "And yet, *I* am the one who *improved* it. Tell me, Your Honor—when was the last time that boy woke up from *your* dream with his sheets *damp*?" First Love turned an impressive shade of puce. Dream’s eye twitched. Mora pressed on. "Exactly. The boy is *thriving* under my care. He’s *engaged*. He’s *feeling*. He’s—" "*Traumatized*," First Love hissed. Dream sighed. He had already made his decision, but the law of the Dreaming required *theater*. "Very well. The court finds in favor of—" A sudden *thump* echoed through the chamber. All three turned to see a small, disheveled figure stumble forward—a mortal boy, Max, still in his pajamas, his hair sticking up in every direction. He blinked blearily at the proceedings, rubbing his eyes. "Uh," he said. "Hi. Sorry. I think I fell asleep in class." Dream stared at him. Then, very slowly, he said, "You are *not* supposed to be here." Max yawned. "Yeah, well, neither is *she*." He pointed at Mora, who waved cheerfully. First Love clapped his hands together. "Your Honor! The *victim* is here! Let him testify!" Dream massaged his temples. "This is *highly* irregular." Max scratched his head. "So, like… is this a dream?" "Yes," Dream said. "Cool." Max turned to Mora. "So, uh… about the whole sitting-on-my-chest thing—" Mora grinned. "Yes, darling?" Max shifted uncomfortably. "It’s… kinda hot?" First Love made a sound like a deflating balloon. Mora preened. "See?" Dream’s fingers curled into fists. "This is *not* helping your case, Mora." Max frowned. "But also, like… it’s *terrifying*? And I wake up feeling like I got hit by a truck? But also…" He trailed off, blushing furiously. Dream’s expression darkened. "I *see*." First Love threw his hands up. "This is *madness*! The boy is *confused*!" Mora smirked. "The boy is *alive*." Dream stood abruptly, his robes billowing like storm clouds. "Enough. The court finds in favor of… *neither* of you." Silence. First Love’s jaw dropped. "What?" Mora’s grin faltered. "Excuse me?" Dream’s eyes gleamed with something dangerously close to mischief. "The dreamscape is *contested*. Therefore, it shall be… *shared*." First Love paled. "Shared?!" Mora’s eyes narrowed. "How?" Dream smiled—a slow, terrible thing. "Simple. The dream will *alternate*. One night, it will be First Love’s pastoral idyll. The next, it will be Mora’s… *breath-stealing seduction*." First Love looked horrified. Mora looked intrigued. Max, meanwhile, perked up. "Wait, so like… I get *both*?" Dream’s smile widened. "Oh, yes. And the best part?" He leaned forward, his voice dropping to a whisper. "The *girl* will never know which version she’s in." Mora cackled. First Love made a small, strangled noise. Dream clapped his hands. "Case closed." As the court dissolved into chaos, Max yawned again, already fading back into the waking world. "Cool," he mumbled. "This is gonna be *weird*." And somewhere in the dark, Dream allowed himself a small, satisfied chuckle.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt's requirements, successfully creating a dark fantasy courtroom scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream. The author effectively captures the essence of Neil Gaiman's Sandman universe, particularly Dream's characterization as an irritated, powerful being forced to deal with petty disputes. The characterizations are well-executed and nuanced. Dream's growing irritation is palpable throughout, from his internal monologue ("Judge Dream, Presiding Over This Utter Nonsense") to his eventual mischievous resolution. First Love is portrayed as an earnest, somewhat pompous entity whose indignation feels authentic, while Mora's pragmatic amorality ("A girl's gotta eat, you know?") provides effective dark humor. The unexpected appearance of Max adds genuine surprise and complicates the proceedings in a believable way. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinct voice. Mora's casual dismissiveness, First Love's theatrical outrage, and Dream's increasingly strained patience create effective comedic tension. The exchanges feel natural while maintaining the fantastical setting's otherworldly quality. The prose strikes an appropriate balance between descriptive and spare, following the prompt's instruction to use descriptives sparingly. The opening description of the court establishes atmosphere without becoming overwrought, and the writing maintains good flow throughout. The dark humor is well-calibrated, deriving from the absurdity of immortal beings arguing over a teenager's dreams while dealing with genuinely uncomfortable subject matter. The comedy emerges naturally from character interactions rather than forced jokes. The resolution is creative and appropriately mischievous for Dream's character. Rather than a simple ruling, he creates a solution that satisfies his sense of cosmic justice while potentially making everyone involved miserable - very much in keeping with his established personality. However, there are some minor weaknesses. The piece occasionally relies on familiar courtroom drama tropes, and some of the humor, while effective, doesn't push into truly innovative territory. The emotional complexity, while present, could be deeper - particularly in exploring the genuine discomfort of the situation being adjudicated. The writing demonstrates technical competence with natural sentence flow and engaging pacing. The author successfully balances multiple tonal elements without the piece becoming incoherent or overwrought. + Fanfic-crossover: Blood Moon — Score: 75.7
Prompt:
Blood Moon Alucard & Yennefer Write a story where Alucard (Hellsing) encounters Yennefer (The Witcher) in medieval Europe. Yennefer's magical abilities intrigue the vampire, while she's both repulsed and fascinated by his monstrous nature. Their power dynamic shifts constantly as they circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first. **Alucard (Hellsing)** Alucard is an ancient, immensely powerful vampire who works for the Hellsing Organization. He can regenerate from almost any wound and shape-shift at will. He's sadistic, arrogant, and takes pleasure in toying with his enemies before killing them. Despite being a monster, he despises weak vampires who can't accept their nature. He wears a distinctive red coat, wide-brimmed hat, and orange sunglasses. He uses massive handguns loaded with silver bullets. He seeks worthy opponents who can challenge him and potentially end his immortal existence. Famous quote: "The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame." **Yennefer of Vengerberg (The Witcher)** Yennefer is a powerful sorceress who magically altered her appearance to hide her congenital hunchback. She's ambitious, stubborn, and manipulative when necessary. She has violet eyes and smells of lilac and gooseberries. Despite her cold exterior, she desperately wants to reverse her infertility caused by magical transformation. She's centuries old but appears young. She's politically savvy and refuses to be underestimated. She has a sarcastic sense of humor and little patience for fools. Though she rarely shows it, she's capable of deep love and loyalty. Famous quote: "I'm not sweet and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Blood Moon** The crimson harvest moon bleeds across the sky, its light staining the cobblestones of the deserted village. The air reeks of iron and damp earth—too much iron for a place so small. Alucard tilts his head, the brim of his hat casting a shadow over his smirk. His fingers twitch around the grip of *Casull*, the silver-plated revolver heavy in his palm. A scent cuts through the stench of death. Lilac and gooseberries. *Magic.* His grin widens. A worthy distraction. --- Yennefer steps over the corpse of a peasant, her boots clicking against the blood-slick stones. The village is a graveyard, the bodies torn apart with a brutality that even she finds excessive. *Vampire.* Not just any vampire—something older, something *hungry.* She exhales, the cold night air curling around her like a lover’s fingers. Then she sees him. A man—or what passes for one—lounging against the skeletal remains of a church door. His coat is the color of fresh blood, his hat obscuring his face. But she knows. She *feels* the weight of his gaze, the predatory amusement rolling off him in waves. "Well," she drawls, flicking a lock of raven hair over her shoulder. "Aren’t you a *charming* sight." Alucard chuckles, the sound like gravel under a boot. "And you, my dear, smell like a garden. How… *quaint.*" He pushes off the doorframe, his movements fluid, unnatural. "Tell me, sorceress—did you come to admire the view, or are you here to die?" Yennefer’s violet eyes narrow. "I don’t die for *men.*" The word drips with disdain. "And you, bloodsucker, are barely that." His laughter rings out, sharp and mocking. "Oh, I *like* you." He twirls *Casull* around his finger before leveling it at her. "But let’s see if you can back up that tongue." --- The first spell comes without warning. A whip of violet fire lashes from Yennefer’s fingertips, searing the air between them. Alucard dodges, his body blurring into a swarm of bats mid-leap. The flames scorch the church wall, leaving blackened streaks in their wake. He reforms behind her, one hand gripping her wrist before she can cast again. His breath is hot against her ear. "Clever. But not *clever enough.*" Yennefer snarls, twisting free with a burst of telekinetic force. She stumbles back, her chest heaving. "You’re faster than I expected." "Flattery won’t save you." Alucard’s grin is all teeth. "But do go on." She doesn’t. Instead, she raises her hands, and the ground beneath him *shudders.* The cobblestones crack, spikes of stone erupting where he stood. But he’s already gone, a shadow melting into the night. Yennefer curses. "Coward." A whisper in the dark. "*Afraid?*" She whirls, but he’s already on her, one hand wrapped around her throat, lifting her off the ground. His strength is inhuman, his grip unbreakable. She gasps, nails digging into his wrist, but he only laughs. "Pathetic," he purrs. "Is this all the great Yennefer of Vengerberg can muster?" Her vision swims. With the last of her strength, she *sings*—a single, discordant note that shatters the air. Alucard hisses, his grip loosening just enough for her to slam her palm into his chest. Light erupts. The force of the spell sends him crashing through the church wall, timber and stone exploding around him. Yennefer lands in a crouch, coughing, her throat raw. She wipes blood from her lip and smirks. "Still standing, *darling.*" --- Alucard emerges from the rubble, his coat singed, his sunglasses cracked. He’s *laughing.* "Now *that* was fun." He cracks his neck, the sound like snapping branches. "But let’s see how you fare when I stop playing nice." The air *presses* in around her. Yennefer’s breath hitches as shadows coil at her feet, slithering up her legs like serpents. She chants, weaving a barrier of light, but the darkness *eats* it, swallowing her magic whole. Alucard steps forward, his form flickering between man and beast. "You’re strong," he admits, almost grudgingly. "But strength means nothing if you can’t *use* it." Yennefer bares her teeth. "And what would *you* know about strength, leech? You hide behind your guns and your games because you’re afraid to face something you can’t control." The words hit like a blade. Alucard’s smile vanishes. For a heartbeat, something *raw* flickers in his crimson eyes—something ancient, something *hungry.* Then he moves. --- The world becomes a blur of claws and spells. Yennefer’s magic clashes against Alucard’s monstrous speed, each strike a thunderous detonation of power. She summons storms; he becomes the storm, a whirlwind of fangs and fury. She hurls fire; he drinks it, his body regenerating faster than she can burn him. And yet— Neither falls. Neither yields. Yennefer’s breath comes in ragged gasps, her body aching from the sheer force of their battle. Alucard is a mess of torn flesh and gore, his coat in tatters, his hat long since lost to the wind. But his eyes—*oh, his eyes*—are alight with something like *joy.* "You’re *exhausting,*" she pants, wiping sweat from her brow. Alucard wipes blood from his chin. "And you’re *annoying.*" He tilts his head. "But… not *boring.*" Yennefer scoffs. "High praise from a corpse." He grins, all teeth. "I’m not dead yet, sorceress." "Neither am I," she counters. A beat of silence. The crimson moon watches them, its light painting their faces in hues of blood and shadow. Alucard exhales, the tension in his shoulders easing. "…Perhaps we should call it a draw." Yennefer considers him. Then, slowly, she nods. "For now." He offers a mocking bow. "Until next time, *Yennefer of Vengerberg.*" She doesn’t watch him leave. But when the last of his presence fades from the air, she allows herself a small, satisfied smile. *Let him think he won.* The night is long. And she has centuries to prove him wrong.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and character understanding, delivering an engaging supernatural confrontation that largely fulfills the prompt requirements. The author successfully captures both characters' essential traits - Alucard's sadistic playfulness and regenerative abilities, and Yennefer's magical prowess and stubborn pride. The medieval European setting is established efficiently through atmospheric details like cobblestones and church architecture. The narrative structure works well, alternating between the characters' perspectives to build tension before their inevitable clash. The combat sequences are visceral and well-choreographed, showing both characters' abilities without making either seem definitively superior. The dialogue captures their personalities effectively, with Alucard's mocking arrogance and Yennefer's sharp retorts feeling authentic to their source materials. However, the piece suffers from some stylistic issues. The prose occasionally veers into purple territory with phrases like "the crimson harvest moon bleeds across the sky" and "her boots clicking against the blood-slick stones." While atmospheric, these descriptions sometimes feel overwrought. The combat descriptions, while exciting, occasionally rely on dramatic formatting and italicized emphasis that feels somewhat amateurish. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - neither character truly wins, maintaining the power dynamic tension requested in the prompt. Yennefer's final internal monologue provides a satisfying sense of her calculating nature without being overly positive given the violent encounter. The characterizations remain consistent throughout, with both figures displaying their canonical traits convincingly. The mutual respect that develops feels earned through their evenly matched battle, and the temporary truce aligns with both characters' pragmatic natures. Some dialogue exchanges feel slightly generic for supernatural beings of their caliber, and certain action sequences could benefit from more restraint in their dramatic presentation. The piece also occasionally tells rather than shows emotional states, particularly in describing the characters' internal reactions. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 13 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 9 Overwrought: 10 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 13.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 8.0, Purple Prose: 9.0, Overwrought: 10.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 68.4
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Prison Strings** The fluorescent lights in Green Dolphin Street Prison flicker like dying fireflies, casting long, jagged shadows across the concrete walls. Jolyne Cujoh leans against the bars of her cell, arms crossed, her butterfly tattoo peeking out from under her sleeve. She’s been here for months, framed for a murder she didn’t commit, but she’s not the type to break. Not yet. Then she sees *her*. A woman in a crisp white coat strides down the hall, her auburn hair tied back in a neat ponytail, her yellow-ringed eyes scanning the cells with detached curiosity. She moves like she owns the place—which, given the way the guards straighten up as she passes, might not be far from the truth. Jolyne’s fingers twitch. *Who the hell is this bitch?* Makima stops in front of her cell, tilting her head. "You must be Jolyne Cujoh," she says, her voice soft, almost sweet. "I’ve heard so much about you." Jolyne doesn’t move. "Yeah? Well, I ain’t heard shit about you, so why don’t you save us both the time and fuck off?" Makima’s lips curl into a smile that doesn’t reach her eyes. "How rude. I was hoping we could be friends." "Friends don’t frame people for murder," Jolyne snaps. "And they sure as hell don’t walk into a prison like they own it." Makima’s smile widens. "Oh, but I *do* own it. At least, for now." She reaches into her coat and pulls out a small, silver key. The lock on Jolyne’s cell clicks open. Jolyne doesn’t move. "What’s the catch?" "No catch," Makima says, stepping inside. "I just want to see your Stand in action." Jolyne’s eyes narrow. *How the hell does she know about Stone Free?* Before she can react, Makima’s hand darts out, gripping her wrist. A jolt of cold shoots up Jolyne’s arm, her muscles locking in place. She tries to pull away, but her body won’t respond. "Relax," Makima murmurs. "I just want to talk." Jolyne grits her teeth. "Talk? You’re *controlling* me." Makima tilts her head. "Isn’t that what friends do? Guide each other?" Jolyne’s free hand twitches. *Stone Free.* Her body unravels into a tangle of glowing green strings, slipping free from Makima’s grip. She reforms a few feet away, fists clenched. "I don’t know what game you’re playing, but I ain’t your puppet." Makima’s expression doesn’t change. "How fascinating. A Stand that turns you into string. I’ve never seen anything like it." Jolyne doesn’t lower her guard. "Cut the act. You’re not here to make friends." Makima sighs, as if disappointed. "You’re right. I’m here to *test* you." She snaps her fingers. The cell door slams shut behind her. The lights flicker, then die, plunging them into darkness. A low, guttural growl echoes from the shadows. Jolyne’s strings tense. *What the hell is that?* A pair of glowing red eyes appear in the dark. Something *moves*—fast, too fast. Jolyne barely dodges as claws rake the air where her head was a second ago. Makima’s voice cuts through the chaos. "Fight it. Or die." Jolyne doesn’t need to be told twice. She lashes out with Stone Free, her strings whipping through the air like a net. The creature snarls as they wrap around its limbs, but it tears free with unnatural strength. *This ain’t no normal prison.* Makima watches, arms crossed, her expression unreadable. "Impressive. But can you do it without getting hurt?" Jolyne doesn’t answer. She’s too busy dodging another swipe, her strings reforming into a shield just in time. The creature lunges again— —and Makima *moves.* One second, she’s standing by the wall. The next, she’s between Jolyne and the monster, her hand pressed against its chest. The creature freezes, its red eyes widening in terror. Makima’s voice is a whisper. "Sleep." The monster collapses, dissolving into shadows. Jolyne stares. "What the *fuck* was that?" Makima turns to her, her smile back in place. "A test. And you passed." Jolyne doesn’t buy it. "You set this up." "Of course I did," Makima says, as if it’s obvious. "I needed to see what you’re capable of." Jolyne’s fists clench. "And what if I *hadn’t* passed?" Makima’s smile doesn’t waver. "Then you’d be dead. But you’re not." She steps closer, her voice dropping to a whisper. "You’re *interesting.*" Jolyne doesn’t flinch. "I don’t give a shit what you think. Stay the hell away from me." Makima chuckles. "Oh, Jolyne. We’re just getting started." The lights flicker back on. Makima is gone. Jolyne exhales, her strings retreating back into her body. She knows one thing for sure—this prison just got a whole lot more dangerous. And Makima? She’s not just a warden. She’s a *hunter.*
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This story successfully establishes the requested crossover scenario between Jolyne Cujoh and Makima in a supernatural prison setting. The author demonstrates a solid understanding of both characters' core traits and abilities, with Jolyne's hot-headed, suspicious nature contrasting effectively against Makima's manipulative sweetness. The characterization is largely faithful to the source materials. Jolyne's dialogue captures her crude, defiant personality ("Yeah? Well, I ain't heard shit about you, so why don't you save us both the time and fuck off?"), while Makima's controlled, predatory nature comes through in her calculated actions and false pleasantries. The author effectively uses Jolyne's Stand ability Stone Free and hints at Makima's control powers. The prose maintains a consistent third-person present tense throughout, with generally solid pacing that builds tension effectively. The opening imagery of flickering fluorescent lights and concrete walls establishes the prison atmosphere well. The action sequences, particularly Jolyne's escape from Makima's control and the monster fight, are clearly written and easy to follow. However, the story suffers from some structural and stylistic weaknesses. The monster encounter feels somewhat arbitrary - while it serves to demonstrate both characters' abilities, it lacks organic integration into the plot. The creature appears and disappears without sufficient explanation, making it feel like a convenient plot device rather than a meaningful story element. The dialogue, while character-appropriate, occasionally relies on exposition ("A Stand that turns you into string. I've never seen anything like it.") rather than more natural conversation. Some moments feel rushed, particularly Makima's sudden disappearance at the end, which seems more like a dramatic flourish than a logical conclusion. The writing occasionally veers toward telling rather than showing, particularly in describing the characters' motivations and the prison's supernatural nature. The ending, while appropriately ominous, feels somewhat abrupt and doesn't fully capitalize on the psychological tension that was building between the characters. The story succeeds in creating an engaging premise and maintaining reader interest, but falls short of fully exploring the rich potential of this character dynamic. The "battle of wits" mentioned in the prompt is more implied than fully realized, with the confrontation remaining relatively surface-level. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 16 Believable Character Actions: 15 Nuanced Characters: 13 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14 Elegant Prose: 13 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 11 Coherent: 15 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 9 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 14 Overall Impression: 13
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 16.0, Believable Character Actions: 15.0, Nuanced Characters: 13.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14.0, Elegant Prose: 13.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 11.0, Coherent: 15.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 8.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 9.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10.0, Amateurish: 8.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 14.0, Overall Impression: 13.0
+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 79.1
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**SCP-XXXX - "The Notes from Tomorrow"** **Object Class:** Euclid (Provisional) **Special Containment Procedures:** Researcher Dr. Elias Voss (hereafter referred to as "Voss") is to be reassigned to low-security archival duty under the supervision of Dr. L. Carter. Voss is to be denied access to any Foundation database containing information on temporal anomalies, memetic hazards, or cognitohazardous entities. All personal effects belonging to Voss are to be confiscated and stored in a secure locker (Designation: Locker-XXXX-7) for analysis. Voss is to undergo weekly psychological evaluations by Dr. R. Patel. In the event that Voss reports receiving additional notes, the following protocol is to be enacted: 1. The note is to be immediately confiscated and placed in a Type-3 cognitohazard containment locker. 2. Voss is to be placed in a standard observation cell for 48 hours. 3. Site-19’s Anomalous Temporal Phenomena Division (ATPD) is to be notified. **Description:** SCP-XXXX refers to a series of handwritten notes appearing in the possession of Dr. Elias Voss, a Level 3 researcher assigned to Site-19’s Historical Anomalies Department. The notes are written in Voss’s handwriting and contain warnings about an impending containment breach of an unspecified entity, referred to as "SCP-████." The notes exhibit increasing desperation, incoherence, and contradictions with established Foundation records. The first note (XXXX-1) was discovered on 2023/05/12 in Voss’s locked desk drawer. Subsequent notes have appeared in sealed containers, Voss’s personal journal, and once inside a sealed evidence bag containing a non-anomalous artifact (Item #19-ARC-2041). Despite security measures, the notes continue to manifest. --- ### **Personal Log of Dr. Elias Voss – 2023/05/15** I found the first note three days ago. It was tucked into the back of my desk drawer, beneath a stack of declassified files on SCP-1471. Just a single sheet of standard Foundation memo paper, folded in half. My handwriting. No date. > *Elias,* > *You need to listen to me. This isn’t a joke. SCP-████ is going to breach. Not if—when. You have to stop it. The Foundation won’t believe you, but you have to try. Don’t trust Carter. Don’t trust Patel. They’re already compromised.* > *—You* I showed it to Dr. Carter during our weekly review. He laughed. Said I must’ve been working too hard. Joked that maybe I’d finally cracked under the pressure. I laughed too. But I didn’t sleep that night. --- ### **Note XXXX-2 – Recovered 2023/05/16** *Location: Inside Voss’s personal journal, beneath a false back cover.* > *They’re watching you now. You showed them the first note. Stupid. Stupid. They think you’re unstable. That’s good. Let them. But you have to move faster. The breach is closer than you think. SCP-████ isn’t what the files say. It’s not a memetic hazard. It’s a* ***thing*** *that wears people. Like a skin. And it’s already here.* > > *Burn this after reading.* I didn’t burn it. I locked it in my desk. Checked the drawer every hour. Nothing else appeared that day. --- ### **Psychological Evaluation – Dr. R. Patel – 2023/05/17** **Patel:** You seem agitated, Elias. Sleep deprivation? **Voss:** I’m fine. **Patel:** You’ve been checking your desk every twenty minutes since you sat down. **Voss:** Habit. **Patel:** You understand why we’re concerned, don’t you? These notes—if they’re real—are a massive security risk. If they’re not… well, we need to rule out psychological factors. **Voss:** They’re real. **Patel:** [sighs] Elias, there’s no record of SCP-████ in any database. No incident reports, no containment procedures. Nothing. **Voss:** Then how do I know about it? **Patel:** That’s what we’re trying to figure out. --- ### **Note XXXX-3 – Recovered 2023/05/18** *Location: Inside a sealed evidence bag (Item #19-ARC-2041, a non-anomalous 19th-century pocket watch).* > *They’re going to take your access. They’re going to call you crazy. Let them. It’s safer that way. But you have to remember: the breach happens during the blackout. The one they won’t talk about. The one that never happened.* > > *You’ll know it when you see it. The lights will go out. The cameras will die. And then* ***it*** *will be in the walls.* > > *Don’t let it touch you. Don’t let it* ***wear*** *you.* > > *P.S. Patel isn’t Patel. Not anymore.* I showed this one to Carter. He didn’t laugh. He just stared at me for a long time, then called security. They took my keycard. Confiscated my journal. Put me in a white room with a camera in the corner. I didn’t sleep that night either. --- ### **Security Footage Transcript – Observation Cell 7 – 2023/05/19** *[Voss sits on the bed, staring at the wall. At 03:47, he stands abruptly, walks to the corner of the room, and crouches down. He reaches behind the baseboard and pulls out a folded piece of paper. He unfolds it, reads, then crumples it in his fist. He looks directly at the camera.]* **Voss:** You see this? You see what’s happening? *[He smooths the paper out and holds it up to the camera.]* > *They’re in the walls now. You have to get out. The next note will be the last. It’s already too late for me. Don’t let it take you too.* > > *P.S. The blackout starts in three days. You’ll know when the lights flicker.* *[Voss stands, walks to the sink, and runs the paper under water until it dissolves.]* --- ### **Interdepartmental Memo – Dr. L. Carter to ATPD – 2023/05/20** **Subject:** Re: Potential Temporal Anomaly – Researcher Voss Dr. Holloway, Attached are the recovered notes from Dr. Voss, as well as transcripts of his behavior over the past 72 hours. While initial assessments suggested a psychological breakdown, the specificity of the warnings—particularly regarding the "blackout" event—warrants further investigation. Key points of concern: - Voss’s description of SCP-████ does not match any known entity in Foundation records. - The "blackout" event he references does not appear in any incident logs. However, a power fluctuation was recorded on 2023/05/01, during which Site-19’s surveillance systems experienced a 12-minute outage. No cause was determined. - Voss’s handwriting analysis confirms the notes were written by him, but the ink composition is inconsistent with any pens in his possession. Recommendation: Assign a temporal anomaly specialist to monitor Voss. If this is a legitimate precognitive event, we need to determine the source before the predicted breach occurs. —Dr. L. Carter --- ### **Personal Log of Dr. Elias Voss – 2023/05/21** They moved me to a new cell today. No windows. No furniture except a bed and a toilet. They took my shoes. I found the fourth note tucked into the waistband of my scrubs. > *It’s in the walls. It’s in the* ***walls*** *and it’s laughing. You can hear it if you listen. It sounds like static. Like screaming.* > > *The blackout starts tomorrow. You’ll see. The lights will flicker, and then the cameras will go dark, and then* ***it*** *will be in the room with you. It will ask you if you want to know what it feels like to be* ***free.*** > > *Don’t answer.* > > *Burn this. Burn yourself if you have to.* I didn’t burn it. I flushed it. I don’t know if that’s enough. --- ### **Incident Report – Site-19 – 2023/05/22** **Time:** 23:17 **Location:** Observation Cell Block 3 At approximately 23:17, Site-19 experienced a total power failure. Backup generators failed to engage. Surveillance systems recorded 18 minutes of static before power was restored. During the blackout, Researcher Voss was observed via infrared camera in Observation Cell 7. Footage shows Voss standing in the center of the room, staring at the wall. At 23:24, Voss began speaking to an unseen presence. Audio pickup was nonfunctional, but lip-reading analysis suggests the following exchange: **Voss:** What do you want? **[Unintelligible response]** **Voss:** No. **[Unintelligible response]** **Voss:** I said no. At 23:29, Voss began screaming. The camera feed cut out at 23:32. When power was restored, Voss was found unconscious on the floor. No physical injuries were observed. Voss was unresponsive to verbal stimuli until 01:12, at which point he awoke and immediately requested to speak to Dr. Carter. **Addendum (01:35):** Voss was found holding a fifth note. Transcript below: > *It’s too late. It’s already wearing you. You just don’t know it yet.* > > *I’m sorry.* Voss was sedated and placed in medical restraints. Current status: Unresponsive. **End Log.** --- **Final Addendum (2023/05/23):** Researcher Voss was found dead in his cell at 06:47. Cause of death: Self-inflicted lacerations to the wrists and throat. A sixth note was recovered from his hand, written in blood: > *Now you understand.* Autopsy revealed no signs of external coercion. However, dental records indicate that Voss’s teeth had been filed down to points post-mortem. SCP-████ remains unconfirmed. Investigation ongoing.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP report demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of the Foundation's clinical documentation style while crafting an engaging psychological horror narrative. The author successfully balances the bureaucratic tone of official SCP documentation with the personal terror of the researcher's experience through alternating formats - official reports, personal logs, interview transcripts, and security footage. The structure is well-executed, beginning with standard containment procedures and escalating through increasingly desperate personal accounts. The use of multiple document types creates authenticity and allows for varied perspectives on the unfolding events. The progression from skeptical dismissal to mounting dread is well-paced. The central mystery - whether this represents genuine temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation - remains effectively ambiguous throughout. The author plants seeds of doubt about reality while maintaining internal consistency within the narrative's logic. The recurring motif of "wearing" people and the entity "in the walls" creates a coherent threat without over-explaining. Character development is solid within the constraints of the format. Voss's deterioration feels believable, moving from professional skepticism to paranoid desperation. Supporting characters like Carter and Patel serve their functions adequately, though they remain somewhat functional rather than fully realized. The ending delivers genuine horror through its implications rather than explicit gore. The detail about filed teeth is particularly effective - subtle enough to be missed on first reading but deeply unsettling upon reflection. The final note's brevity contrasts powerfully with the earlier desperate warnings. Some weaknesses include occasional repetitive phrasing and a few moments where the clinical tone slips into more conventional horror writing. The dialogue, while serviceable, lacks distinctive character voices. The middle section occasionally feels slightly padded, though this may be intentional to mirror the repetitive nature of bureaucratic documentation. The piece succeeds in creating genuine unease through its format and escalating uncertainty about reality, making effective use of the SCP universe's established conventions while telling an original story. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
